Dr. Louis Lasagna, of the
Hopkins School of Medicine has
announced that three professors
will offer a special seminar on
behavior analysis and
environmental design to medical
students and to graduates and
undergraduates at the University
during the second semester.
Dr. Joseph V. Brady, Dr.
Richard Allen Chase and Mr.
Roger M. Downs have designed
this special course to introduce
students to the relationships
between behavior analysis and
environmental design. The course
will include three specific design
Projects as well as lectures and
discussions. The class will consist
Of 24 students who will be
divided into 3 teams of 8 students
each for the specific projects. One
of the 3 professors will serve as an
advisor to each group.

** CAMPUS NOTES **
JOURNEY INTO
NIGHT
Hopkins nomads lusting for
adventure on a - tour through
Europe, North Africa, the Middle
East, and the Soviet Union, in the
summer of 1969, should
communicate with K. William
Viehe, Box 135, American
University, Washington, D.C. The
trip lasts for 12 weeks and costs
around $1500.

KEG PARTIES
On Friday, January 10, at 10 p.m.
the Graduate Club continues, its
time honored tradition of Keg
Parties, where free beer and music

will be dispensed till the wee
hours. Our usually modest
admission charges will still be in
effect. The party will be held at
the Club in McCoy Hall.
COED RELIGION
Goucher and Hopkins JSA are
holding a joint service 5 p.m. this
Friday at Haebler Chapel. Rides
leave the Hop at 4:30 from the
Dorm lot.
FINAL TRIP
Chester's Place will be holding its
last session of this semester this
week. Monolith and Stanley
Hahn's King Biscuit will be there,
along with Mike Atherton's folk
group, returning after a very
successful session last November.
A fourth group, with Larry
Sarezky and Steve Mann, may be
there.
The prices are the same, the
menu is the same. The mural is
almost finished. Friday night at 9
p.m.

HE DIGS
THE QUEEN
College students are needed to
work in England this summer for
various archaeological 'digs'
throughout the British Isles. The
program costs $750 and includes
a 3 week training program at
Merton College, Oxford.
Applications must be received by
February, 1969. Write to: Prof.
Ian A. Lowson, Assoc. for
Cultural Exchange, 539 W. 112th
St. New York, N.Y. 10025.
A.B.-M.A. MEETING
There will be a meeting of all past
and present AB-MA's in the
Sherwood Room, Monday,
January 13, at 7:30 p.m.
WEINBERG WEDS
The Student Association will
present a special movie this
Saturday, Jan. 11, at 8 p.m. in
Levering Hall. The film is the
HUSTLER, starring Jackie
Gleason and Paul Newman.

Admission is $1.00 for general
audiences and 75 cents for SA
members, SA social members
admitted free of charge.
SURGICAL SUMMER
Any Pennsylvania resident going
to Hopkins can apply for the
James A. Finnegan Fellowship
Foundation Awards, the top
honor being six weeks internship
to be served at any time between
June and September at a weekly
stipend of $125.00. Closing date
for Applications is March 1, 1969.
For forms write to James A.
Finnegan Fellowship Foundation,
510 North Third Street,
Harrisburg, Pennsylvania 17101.

The American Association of

Nothing helps a young engineer's
career like being given a challenge.
Which is another way of saying a chance
to fail now and then. To make his own
mistakes.
At Western Electric we give our newly
recruited engineers responsibility almost
immediately. They make their own decisions. Learn from their own errors.
Don't get us wrong. We keep our

demands reasonable enough so that our
recruits can make their decisions at their
own pace. But our thinking is, a man
feels awfully good about even a small
decision when it's his.
If you're the type who'd like the chance
to make your own moves,see our recruiter
or write College Relations, 222 Broadway, New York, N. Y. 10038.

News Briefs
New Turmoil...
To start off the new year, San Francisco State College is
gripped in a strike by one third of its faculty members, a supportive
strike by the unionized campus employees and. sporadic student
Picketing demonstrating and jeers.
The members of the American Federation of Teachers at the
college have supported student strikers who have boycotted classes
since November 6. There are 1,100 teachers and 18,000 students.
and minorities in both are striking for more say in the college's
policy decisions. This week classes were full, but professors sparce.
Until this development, Acting President S.I. Hayakawa was quite
Optimistic in keeping the school open. But now he says, "I don't
know how I am going to stop them from closing the school. But am
going to try." The College of San Mateo in California has been
rampaged in recent weeks by students in support of San Francisco
collegues.

action of the S.O. was prompted

While Gov. Talks Tough
Meanwhile, Governor Reagan has called for a get tough policy
in regard to campus turmoil. The new policy was stated in the
governor's "State of the State" message before a joint session of the
California legislature. This is the first year that the Republicans have
held a majority in both houses.
Reagan hopes to curb student and faculty disturbances by
increasing the pennies for disruptive action. He told the legislature,
"I will seek an omnibus program on the safety and security of our
educational institutions— to protect the teacher, the student and the
public."

Space Program Aided
Hopkins scientists observed last week a monitoring device
orbiting the earth to check solar radiation and cosmic rays. Dr. Carl
0. Bostrom headed the team at the Hopkins' Applied Physics
Laboratory in Silver Spring, which developed particle detectors for
an Interplanetary Monitoring Platform.
The platform called Explorer 34 is a 138 pound,
octagon-shaped satellite. It was launched in May 1967. Four tracking
stations were monitoring Explorer 38, and they sent their
information to Goddard Space Flight Center in Greenbelt, Maryland.
From there, it is forwarded to Houston for use of the astronauts or
their program planners.
Although the astronauts are shielded against radiation that
approaches being hazardous, bombardment of particles from an
unusual solar eruption is always a potential danger according to the
scientists. If such an eruption develops, the tracking stations will
step up their monitoring of the space platform. Solar proton
velocities can reach near the speed of light.

81)8 Expands Rase I The Student Revolt
At its quarterly National
Council meeting in Ann Arbor,
Michigan in late December, SDS
took initial steps to change itself
from solely a college student
movement to a multi-class youth
movement. The National Council
also dealt with •the issues of
Women's Liberation, Inauguration
Day demonstrations and the
Tenth Anniversary of the Cuban
Revolution.
For the last year, SDS has
been discussing and debating the
traditional blue-collar working
class: its importance in modern
capitalism, its role in a movement
for revolutionary change, and
how best to link up with and
organize the "working class" for
such change. SDS has slowly
come to the belief that the
working class is a critical force in
this society, that it should play a
leading role in the movement for
revolutionary change, and that it
is of crucial importance at this
time that the Movement makes,
serious alliances with the working
class, especially its progressive
elements. Radicals emphasize this
by pointing to the important
effects of the worker-student
alliance during the French May
Rebellion.

organize in the Army,in the High
Schools, Working Class Colleges,
trade and technical schools, in the
streets, around these group
similarities and common forms of
oppression which give the lie to
the myth of the American Dream
and the American Consensus. The
formulators do not see youth as a
formal class, and while
maintaining that young and old
workers have more in common
than the young of different
classes, they see this proposal for
a "Revolutionary Youth
Movement" as a means of making
connections with the working
class. It is seen as a temporary
strategy for broadening the base
of the Movement to include the
working class on a significant
scale which will lead to a
movement for revolutionary
change dominated by the working
class.
The National Council also
passed a resolution aimed at
promoting the struggle for
Women's Liberation. SDS sees
that women, like black people
and young people, experience
certain forms of oppression
common to the group. The
primary forms of oppression are
economic: women are
discriminated against in job hiring
and promotion, women are paid
lower wages than men, women
serve as a reserve labor force to
replace men during wartime and
during strikes. Secondarily,
women take a back-seat role to
men socially and politically. The
ideas of the prim and proper
woman who "knows her place",
which is inculcated starting at the

NEW YORK, December 24
- Three militant high school
student organizations have
formed an alliance for future
actions and coordination. This is
an outgrowth of the massive
strike by high school students in
late November and early
December in protest against the
extended \ hours and days of
school which was part of the
settlement of the Teacher's Strike
this fall. The High School Student
Union, the High School Coalition
and the Afro-American Student
Association have formed the High
School Student Council. The
Council will consist of
representatives from the three
organizations and five members at
large. Its purpose will be to help
bridge communications and to
work Logether on a city-wide
basis.

LIMA, December 11 - Three
students were shot and wounded

campus of the University of San

APRA had attempted to enter the
buildings to begin a
demonstration in support of the
Rector, Luis Alberto Sanchez,
member of that party. Sanchez
has been accused of
administrative irregularities by the
San Marco University Federation.

The Draft - Part 103
Though there are ostensibly peace talks going on in Paris and
we are led to believe that this time the South Vietnamese will really
be taking more of a part in the fighting there, the draft still hangs
over the heads of college students facing graduation.
Therefore, as a public service, we offer the following
suggestions for those students who wish to vent their bitterness on
their local Selective Service Boards.
1 - Write a letter to your local board referring to your previous
letter of two weeks ago. (Naturally, there was no previous letter of
two weeks ago). Tell your board that you are awaiting their answer
and are surprised that they have not yet replied. The board's staff is
then obligated to search through their files for your letter, causing
universal grief.
2 - Write a letter to your board, using a fictitious name,
wondering why you have not received your first classification card.
Given a false return address. (If you have time write a dozen or so
letters to this effect). According to our information, when the board
fails to find records of the non-person, and fails to contact him
about the non-existence of his records, they will have to send
someone to investigate. The best method to use here, is to take a few
names from your local phone book who have addresses withint the
jurisdiction of your board.
3 - As a public-spirited citizen, alert your draft board to the
fact that you have heard of plans to raid their office and pour blood
in the 1-A files. This method is best used if you know of someone
(preferably someone you don't like) who plans to visit his draft
board on a specific day on some business. Give a good description of
him. A splendid time is guaranteed for all.
4 - Keep a diary of all the minute things that happen to you in
day-to-day life. Make a carbon for your own personal use, and send
the original closely-hand written 3 pages each day to your board,
preferably addressed to a specific ranking board member. At some
point in one of your daily missives, insert a question pertinent to
your draft status. If the question goes unanswered, write to your
board a few weeks later asking what their reply was to the question
posed in "my letter of the fifteenty... or sixteenth.., or
seventeenth."
5 - Send them a copy of this editorial,(we don't want to go
either).

By ED MENDELSOHN
The Presidential inaugural
ceremonies, soon to be renewed,
have had an interesting evolution.
Inaugurals have been held
indoors, have been held in three
different cities and have had
varying historical significance.
The Constitution provides
only that the President must take
an oath, which is all that is done
in cases of non-quadrennial
succession. However, George ,
Washington was understandably
honored in several communities
when he went north to New York
for the first inaugural in 1789.
This first ceremony was held
outdoors, and Mr. Washington
delivered a long inaugural address.
However, he had neglected to
bring his Bible with him and had
to acquire one in New York. That
the President will hold a Bible in
taking the required oath is as
certain as that he will attend the
ceremonies.
For Mr. Washington's
second inaugural, there seemed no
reason to have more than the
oath taking. Thomas Jefferson was
an especially earnest advocate of
simplicity, and there was a very
brief ceremony within the .Senate
chamber in Philadelphia. Mr.
Washington delivered a statement
of thanks, which may be
considered the shortest inaugural
address, but which was so brief as
to make it a tenable proposition
that there was no inaugural
address in 1793.
Outdoors
John Adams was
inaugurated March 4, 1797 in the
House chamber in Philadelphia,
and since then all inaugurals have
been in Washington, D.C. Mr.
Jefferson's own inaugurals were
not as simple as that which he had
prescribed for Mr. Washington.
Inaugurals alternated between the

chambers of the Senate and the
House until 1817, when there
wasa dispute between the two
Houses over the allocation of
tickets. James Monroe therefore
participated in the second
outdoor inauguration.
The ceremonies reverted to
the indoors until Andrew
Jackson, who desired a
government close to the people,
was inaugurated outdoors in
18_29. Afterwards his supporters
entered the White House, and
committed some property
damage, so that in the famous
words of Supreme Court Justice
Joseph Story of Massachusetts,
"the reign of King Mob seemed
triumphant."
Few inaugurations have
been equally open to
participation. Even then, and
again in the inauguration of
Zachary Taylor in 1849, there
were complaints of insufficient
refreshments. But no President
since has been inaugurated
indoors, despite such incidents as
the rain at James K. Polk's
inauguration in 1845.
No Notes
Only one president,
Franklin Pierce in 1853, delivered
his inaugural address without
reading from notes. Mr. Pierce
had been among the leading trial
lawyers of New Hampshire, and
his oratorical powers were quite
equal to this occasion.
There is 'no lack of
commentary on one of the
milestones of our history, the
inauguration of Abraham Lincoln
on March 4, 1861. To me it is
most arresting that, besides Mr.
Lincoln, so many of those who
played an important role in the
ceremony would not live to see
another President. Mr. Lincoln
was introduced by a former
colleague in the Winois State
Legislature, Senator Edward D.
Baker of Oregon, who died that

autumn at the Battle of Ball's
Bluff. During the inaugural
address Mr. Lincoln's hat was held
by his former adversary, Senator
Stephen A. Douglas, who also had
only months to live. Then the
oath was administered to Mr.
Lincoln by Chief Justice Roger B.
Taney, who had been criticized
by the former for his decision in
the Dred Scott case, and who was
to die on Columbus Day of 1864.
Big-Mouth Coolidge
The twentieth century has
seen two important changes, the
introduction of broadcasting and
the changing of the date from
March 4 to January 20. Radio
first covered the ceremonies on
March 4, 1925, at the
inauguration of Calvin Coolidge.
The oath of office was
administered by Chief Justice
William Howard Taft, himself
inaugurated on the same day
sixteen years before, who noted
that his voice was heard and
recognized in all parts of the
country. The first televised
coverage of the inauguration of
Harry S. Truman on January 20,
1949.
The first President
inaugurated on January 20,
following the enactment of
George Norris' Twentieth
Amendment, was Franklin D.
Roosevelt for his second term in
1937. Had this been the operative
date earlier, John Adams would
have been inhibited from
appointing John Marshall as Chief
Justice.
The inaugural ceremony is
significant as a symbol of unity.
The administering of the oath of
office by the head of the judicial
branch to the head of the
executive branch in front of the
legislative chamber illustrates the
fundamental cohesiveness of the
Federal government.

Before attempting to review
the Beatles' album, I have a
confession to make: I'm a Beatle
teenybopper. When it comes to
Beatlerablia, I'm an insatiable
hog. I scour all the magazines,
newspapers, and rock journals,
my heart throbbing with a 13
year old's excitement, searching
for the merest mention of my
heroes' names. My,tolerance for
even the most inane trivia on the
Beatles is disgustingly enormous.
Is John Lennon's ex-wife writing
a children's book? Is Paul
McCartney's uncle's middle name
Rufus? If so, I'll know about it.
Furthermore, I spend endless
hours of discussion on the most
inconsequential nuances of every
Beatle album. There seems to be
no end to my absorption and
fascination with the Beatles.
Frankly, I'm hooked.
End of Narcissism
The new album is a step
down for the Beatles. Although it
is less intellectually satisfying
than Sgt. Pepper's, it is more fun.
Now for hip young intellectuals
bent on finding great meaning in
the Beatles, this new album is a
disappointment. Part of the
reason for this disappointment are
. the disclaimers of the Beatles
themselves, who say that a lot of
their songs are put-ons, rubbish,
nonsensical,. and meaningless. In
the good old days, one could
spend many fruitful hours poring
over the songs of the Beatles,
finding literary allusions and
hidden meanings to satisfy the
heart of any literary scholar.
Now, of course, we find we can't
find great meaning in obscure
songs like "I Am the Walrus"
because John Lennon won't let
us.
What the Beatles are doing,
and everybody else it seems, is
returning to their roots, their
past. This past was a simpler one,
with easy lyrics and a simple turn.
Songs like "Dizzy Miss Lizzie,"
"Love Me Do," and "P.S. I Love
You," and so on exemplify this
simplicity. The new Stones album
is a similar return to their roots,
which are rhythm and bluesy.

Bethlehem Steel
Loop Course Interviews:

FEBRUARY
10, 11, 1969

.
4

What is the Bethlehem Loop Course? It is our management development program for graduat?s
with bachelors' or advanced degrees.
The course starts early in July with four weeks of orientation at our home offices in Bethlehem,
Pa. Loopers attend lectures on every phase of the corporation's activities, and make almost daily
visits to a steel plant.
Steel Plant Loopers, who comprise a majority of the average loop class of 150 to 200 graduates,
proceed to various plants where they go through a brief orientation program before beginning
their on-the-job training assignments. Within a short time after joining the course, most loopers
are ready for assignments aimed toward higher levels of management.
How about other loopers? Our Sales Department loopers (30 or so) remain at the home office for
about a year of training. Most are then assigned to district offices where they take over established
accounts.
Fabricated Steel Construction loopers are trained in a drafting room, on a field erection project,
in a fabricating shop, and in an engineering office. A looper's first work assignment is based on
interests and aptitudes disclosed during this program.
Loopers in Accounting, Shipbuilding, Mining, Research, Traffic, Purchasing, Finance and Law,
General Services, and Industrial and Public Relations go through training programs tailored to
their types of work.
Where would YOU fit in? Check your degree or the one most similar to it.
MECHANICAL ENGINEERING—Engineering or mechanical maintenance departments of steel plants, fabricating works, mining operations, and shipyards. Fuel and
combustion departments. Supervision of production operations. Marine engineering assignments in Shipbuilding
Department. Also: Sales or Research.
METALLURGICAL ENGINEERING — Metallurgical
departments of Steel plants and manufacturing operations.
Engineering and service divisions. Technical and supervisory positions in steelmaking departments and rolling.
mills. Also: Research or Sales.
,CHEMICAL ENGINEERS—Technical and supervisory
positions in coke works, including production of byproduct chemicals. Fuel and combustion departments, including responsibility for operation and maintenance of air
and water 'pollution control equipment. Engineering and
Metallurgical departments. Steelmaking operations. Also:
Research or Sales.
INDUSTRIAL ENGINEERING —Positions in steel
plants, fabricating works, shipyards, and mines. Engineering and maintenance departments. Supervision of
steelmaking, rolling, manufacturing, and fabricating
operations. Also: Sales.
CIVIL ENGINEERING: Fabricated Steel Construction
assignments in engineering, field erection, or works management. Steel plant, mine, or shipyard assignments in
engineering, construction, and maintenance. Supervision
of production operations. Sales Department assignments
as line salesman or sales engineer (technical service to
architects and engineers).

ELECTRICAL ENGINEERING—Steel plant, fabricating works, mining operations, and shipyard electrical
engineering, construction, and maintenance departments.
Technical and supervisory positions in large production
operations involving sophisticated electrical and electronic equipment. Also: Research or Sales.
MINING ENGINEERING — Our Mining Department
operates coal and iron ore mining operations and limestone quarries, many of which are among the most modern and efficient in the industry. This 10,000-man activity
offers unlimited opportunities to mining engineers. Also:
Research.
NAVAL ARCHITECTS AND MARINE ENGINEERS:
Graduates are urged to inquire about opportunities in our
Shipbuilding Department, including the Central Technical Division, our design and engineering organization.
Also: Traffic.
OTHER TECHNICAL DEGREES—Every year we recruit loopers with technical degrees other than those listed
above. Seniors enrolled in such curricula are encouraged
to sign up for an interview.
ACCOUNTANTS—Graduates in accounting or business
administration (24 hours of accounting are preferred) are
recruited for training for supervisory assignments in our
3,000-man Accounting Department.
OTHER NON-TECHNICAL DEGREES — Graduates
with degrees in liberal arts, business, and the humanities
are invited to discuss opportunities in the Sales Department. Some non-technical graduates may be chosen to fill
openings in steel plant operations and other departments.

NOW'S THE TIME TO SIGN UP FOR AN INTERVIEW. And when you register at the placement office, be sure to pick up a copy of our booklet. "Careers with Bethlehem Steel and the
Loop Course.- It contains important information about the corporation and your opportunities
through the Loop Course.

BETHLEHEM STEEL

in the Plans for Progress Program

By RICH HOLLANDER
Sports Editor

The original Levering bacchanalia, otherwise known as the Fall
Sports Banquet, was held on December 16. Staged .and
choreographed by master of ceremonies, Henry Ciccarone, the three
119ur extravaganza clearly rivaled the Academy Awards in trophies if
not in comic talent. Ciccarone filtered out all the funny lines and
concentrated on the business of the evening. "...going to scout
Carnegie Mellon, Mr. Smith got me tickets on a small Italian airline."
The first order of business was digestion. An almost gruesome
task,- pertaining to some mysterious meat, wrapped in an oblong
shade around Thanksgiving' Day's stuffing, covered with brown
all-purpose gravy. There was a lemon surprise for dessert...that my
dentist would have loved. Our president, Dr. Gordon, rendered a few nonchalant
comments on the games he attended. He looked as in -place at a
sports banquet as General Eckert.
BARRETTE'S BOYS
Prefacing the soccer awards, Coach Gary Barrette gave the
classic line of the affair. "I thought this was going to be a joint
banquet and so far I've ended up eating a football." After that
unpalatable allusion, Barrette praised his soccermen who finished
third out of 17 teams in the Middle Atlantic Conference.
Recognition was givento Jay AB-Stars Rick Tobey, Art Guerin and
Mike Avery in the MAC; and to Tobey, Guerin, and Randy Miller in
the Mason-Dixon Conference. Hardly getting a change to enjoy a
Barrette monologue, Miller and Tobey, were up again capturing
places on the MI-South team. In the trophy department, Dave
Roberts, leading scorer, and Randy Miller, outstanding player, took
the honors. An engraved soccer ball was given by Mr. Barrette to
captain Mike Avery for outstanding sportsmanship: The Booster
Club awarded a mini-trophy to "unsung hero" Greg Sarau. Avery, on
behalf of the team, thanked trainers Leroy Brandimore and Steve
Bartlett and trundled over to Coach Barrette with a varsity "H Club"
jacket. In the '68 soccer swansong Avery announced that Randy
Miller and Dave Roberts were elected co-captains for '69.
SOTIR'S SORTIE
Once upon a while the Jay gridmen were 0-6-2. Two years
have gone by and in that period the varisty eleven have taken two
consectuvie MAC championships. The man to blame for this
achievement, head coach Alex Sotir, spelled out the ingredients in
his championship brew. Take a dash of administrative empathy, a
touch of studen enthusiasm and dump in lots of team pride and
bingo - a championship.
Nevertheless, the trophies went to the bodies who blocked,
'bruised and busted themselves to the championship. Co-captains
Don Yablonowitz and Willie Scroggs received game balls from
Carnegie-Mellon and Western Maryland respectively. The unsung
Boosters picked unsung heroes John Peck and Willie Scroggs for
awards. Don took home a silver cup in memory of Hopkins'
tOotballer Charles E. Aronhalt, who was killed in Vietnam in 1966:
For variety a plaque was given to Joe Cowen for team spirit. The
newly founded Huddle Club gave its second annual contribution
trophy to Phil Schrodel. This trophy was a high rise jqb and was the
gaudiest of the festivities. Representing the MAC, Marshall Turner
made the championship official. Mr. Bilgrave proved to be as
efficient a tie clip distributor as he is an administrator, calling off the
roster in 3 minutes and 6 seconds. Don, like his soccer counterpart,
gave the coaches jackets. Due to close balloting, the '69 team will
have tri-captains. They are Jim Lotto, Charlie Coker and Dan
Rosenfeld. Imagine if they did that in national elections.
IN THE BLUE JERSEY NUMBER 70

MARSHALL KAPP, varsity heavyweight grappler battles against foe from Lebanon Valley College. Jays won
match by score of 24-13 but Kapp lost his bout.

After enduring several years
of frustration because of a lack of
overall power, the varsity gapplers
have finally come into their own.
Beating two relatively
strong teams before Christmas,
the matmen take on the powerful
Indians of Delaware University at
home next Wednesday at 8:00
p.m. with the Baby Jays facing
the Delaware frosh at 6:45 p.m.
In their first match of the
season on December 14th, the
varsity wrestlers completely tore
apart the Shoremen of
Washington College, winning the
contest with a score of 35 to 5.
Rich Dryden, captain of the
team, won the 123 lb. class by
forfeit. Stan Konefal, wrestling in
his first varsity match, decisioned
Kiler by a score of 9-5. The match
was tied 2-2 going into the third
period when the Hopkins
sophomore reversed his opponent
twice and almost had a pin as the
bout ended.

finally won the match on a final
takedown, 6-5 defeating the
captain of the Washington College
team.
Jeff Parker, another
sophomore, wrestling at 145 lb.,
showed why he was last year's
best frosh grappler by going right
for a pin and landing it at exactly
1:09 into the match. Monte
lkemire, the 152 lb. senior from
Oklahoma, followed Parker's act
by pinning his opponent in 7:29.
Jack Hannemann, one of
the few juniors on the team,
continued the pinning ways of the
Jays by defeating his man in 6:01.
Hannemann was leading at the
time by 6-1. John Peck, 177 lb.
senior, who was the unluckiest
wrestler on the team last year,
showed everyone that the jinx
had ended. Peck decisioned
Pramm of Washington College,
6-1, and accumulated over 6
minutes of riding time.

Betta Upends Captain
Carl Betta, also wrestling in
his first varsity contest, fell
behind 2-0 in the first period,
came back to lead the Shoreman
4-3 at the end of the second, and

First Period Decisive
Bob Hyams, the other
junior on the team, defeated his
177 lb. foe in a rough and tumble
match. Charles Conway, another
first year varsity matman,
decisioned Filippi at 191 lb. by
the score of 8-7. It wasn't until
late in the third period that
Conway assured himself of the
win. Filippi was fourth in the
Mason-Dixon tournament last
year.
Marshall Kapp, a very
determined wrestler battling in his
first varsity bout, nearly pinned
his heavyweight opponent during
the first minute of the match; but
Kapp made an unfortunate error
and was pinned at 1:51. Fred
Ryland, wrestling exhibition,
decisioned his foe, 12-4.

All those players who have

and handball tournaments are

We're No Patsies
Opening the home season
against the Flying Dutchmen of
Lebanon Valley College on
December 18, the grapplers were
faced with an experienced and
talented opposition. In previous
years, the Flying Dutchmen
always considered our match as a
means of boosting their record;
but this year, as last year the Blue
Jays came away with the biggest
laugh, beating LVC, 24-13.
Rich Dryden started his
1968-69 tour where he left off
last February before his arm
injury. Dryden easily defeated
Layne of LVC, pinning the 123

lb. foe in 5:45. Dryden was
beating him, 8-0 at the time.
Carl Betta was then down
with a severe virus infection and
was unable to wrestle. Coach Kyle
Smith decided to forfeit the 130
lb. class and have Stan Konefal
move up to 137 lb. The strategy
worked out beautifully as Konefal
decisioned Etchberger, 5-2.
Jeff Parker, who hates to
stay on the mat too long,
recorded his second straight pin;
this one also came in the first
period at 1:56. Monte Ikemire
lost to the Dutchmen's powerful
152 pounder, Rich Althouse, 7-2.
Jack Hanemann decisioned Koons
by the score of 12-7. The score
was tied 7-7 with a minute to go.
John Peck continued his
winning ways, pinning LVC's Bob
Helt in 4:09. Charles Conway,
wrestling in the 177 lb. class for
Bob Hyams who had a bad arm,
battled a tough opponent. Going
into the last period the score was
all tied, but Conway recorded a
near fall and an escape to gain a
9-7 victory.
Marshall Kapp lost the
unlimited bout when Thomas of
LVC pinned him in 3:26. Fred
Ryland, again wrestling an
exhibition bout, pinned his foe in
4:23.
The team is well rested after
the Christmas holidays. Betta is
over the virus and Hyams is
completely healed. Bob Sanborn,
injured early in December, is
slowly coming back to his form.
Winners of the paper bag
award, given after each match to
the wrestler who has been ridden
the longest period of-time, have
been: Conway for the Washington
match and Hanemann for the
LVC victory'. The bag,which is
placed outside the locker of the
lucky individual until the next
match, reads: "You can't even
fight your way out of this paper
bag, never mind another
wrestler." The award, to be sure,
is not one of the more coveted
prizes of the powerful Hopkins
matmen.

NEWS-LETTER

Natators Girding Berke Paces Varsity B-Ballers
For Crucial Meet In Victory Over Swarthmore
By JOSH TREEM
Wednesday, January 15 will
mark the crucial date in J.H.U.'s
varsity swimming season. Fresh
from two pre-Christmas victories
over Swarthmore and Towson
State, and with another win
hopefully in the offing against
PMC tomorrow at Homewood,
the Jays will tackle the University
of Delaware again at home.
First year coach Frank
Comfort considers this meet the
most important in Hopkins
swimming history, and has tried
to convey this attitude to his
swimmers. "Delaware is the one
really outstanding team we swim
in dual meet competition," he
stated. "They're in a class by
themselves."(Delaware does in
fact compete in the MAC
University division while Hopkins
swims in the college division.)
"We could go 10-1, or 9-2 for the
season and everyone would say
'good job', but as far as I'm
concerned this is the big one."
Any thought of beating
Delaware was dismissed as
ludicrous last year. And it is a
tribute to both coach and
swimmers that Hopkins can even
think of challenging Delaware.
Scouting reports indicate that the
contest will be extremely tight.
The Jays hope to have the meet
won before the final event, the
freestyle, where Delaware now
has an edge, and while all races
are crucial, the 50 and 100 yd.
freestyle and the 200 yd.
individual medley loon as key
contests.
Drawing Comfort
In any case, as the Jan. 15
deadline draws closer, certain
elements may work in the Jays
favor and could spell the
difference between victory or
defeat. First is the home pool
advantage. While this is a minor,
consideration because of the
excellent facilities, a partisan
crowd can only help Hopkins. In
addition, the bus ride and a night

meet might find Delaware a bit
tired.
Second is Delaware's
rigorous dual meet schedule
which has them swimming five
meets before meeting Hopkins,
and possibly the swimmers could
be psychologically tired. Third is
the psyche factor. Coach Comfort
has injected a determination into
the Jays previously unknown. As
the Bullets' slogan goes: "We have
a few scores to settle."
Intangible Difference
Indeed, the squad is
pointing for this contest, and
although Delaware must be aware
of the Jays' improvement,
hopefully they will not be taking
the meet as seriously as Comfort's
charges. This intangible could
make all the difference. The meet
is scheduled for 8:30 p.m. on
Wed., Jan. 15, at Homewood
pool.
Tomorrow, the Jays tangle
with PMC at Homewood at 3:00
p.m. Last year Hopkins nipped
the Cadets 47-46. This year's
meet could be as close but it is
unlikely. Mr. Comfort is viewing
the meet as a final tune-up for
Delaware and is not cutting down
on practices. The attitude around
the locker room is one of
confidence. However, PMC has an
outstanding freestyle sprinter and
two fine backstrokers. Heavily
laden with sophomores the Cadets
are basically an unknown
quantity in MAC circles and could
spell trouble for a complacent
Hopkins crew.
In the two meets before
Christmas break, Hopkins easily
beat Swarthmore 53-40 and then
swamped Towson State 65-28.
Highlighting the Towson meet
were Marc Solomon who qualified
for the NCAA college nationals in
the 200 yd. butterfly, Mike
O'Donnell who set a varsity
record in the 200 yd.
breaststroke, and Brian Turner's
100 yd. freestyle record (52.5).

Freshmen Five Down
Gilman in Easy Victory
By MIKE SHORE
The frosh basketball team,
under the direction of Coach
Gary Barrette, had a busy week
before the holiday break, winning
2 games against 1 loss, and
showing off some high quality
To open their season, the
team met Gilman High School,
and coasted to an easy 65-53
victory. The game was never in
the slightest doubt, and all of our
men were given ample chance to
play and show off their talents in
a game situation.
The next game was the first
half of a Saturday evening
Swarthmore Frosh/Varsity
doubleheader. It too was an easy
victory, 84-66.
The high point of this one
was a tremendously spectacular
offensive show by Gary
Handleman. He broke the modern
Hopkins freshman scoring record
by racking up 40 points. He was
16 for 22 from the court for a
72% shooting average, and 8 for 9
from the foul line. Hal Grinberg
was also a big help to the effort
with 17 points.
Playing against a team from
Catholic University, made up
entirely of scholarship players,
our men put on a good
performance and came to within

one point of winning at the end.
The final score was 81-80.
Without a few misfortunes the
frosh could very well have beaten
a team which averaged several
inches taller, and supposedly was
a better class of basketball team

nasty cut on his ear and had to
come out. Then Mike Kohler tore
some ligaments in his ankle and
also left the game. Soon after
John Lilly was taken out by
Barrette because he was in foul
trouble.

It has become increasingly
evident in the past several years
that an acute shortage of trained
doctors may be soon facing the
country.
()pinion is near-unanimously pessimistic. The U.S.
General Surgeon, for example,
estimates that we will need
11,000 M.D.'s a year by 1975 yet
the Association of American
Medical Colleges (AAMC) reports
thii the chalices of producing
more than 9,450 per year by then
is very slim.
lin to
the
prospects of even approaching the
needed increase in graduating
M.D. s is very unlikely. This year
for example, there are
approximately 3.9 doctors per
100,000 while in 1955 the figure
rested at 4.2_ The figures appear
even worse when it is realized that
patients today see their doctor
twice as often as they did 30
years ago.
Overworked
in today's society,
therefore, are few and often
overworked.
In response to the growing
awareness of the great difficulties
towards which Hie country is
moving, there has developed in
recent years, a cry for medical
schools to increase the number of
graduates per year. One
outstanding critic of medical
policies today, Dr. John B.
deC.M. Saunders, former dean
Doctors

for example, is admitting this year
100 extra students to the third
year of the medical program.
These students come primarily
from the seven two-year medical
schools in the country. Because
the two-year schools do not offer
a medical degree, the admission of
the 100 students represents a
total increase in the number 'of
M.D. degrees given.
Dr. Yardley believes that
this admission of students into
the third year will allow for
maximum utilization of
institutional facilities.
Dr. Price also noted that the
Advisory Board is presently
preparing a feasibility study of
the requirements necessary for
increasing the present total
enrollment. After the report is
complete, Dr. Price indicated that
the Medical can then begin to
think in terms of long-range
expansion and eventual increases
in doctors produced by the
School.

and chancellor of the University
of California School of Medicine,
believes that schools across the
country should increase
enrollment by between 15 and 20
per cent. Such a move, he argues,
would produce as many new
doctors as 12 to 16 additional
medical schools.
Despite this need for
expansion of the medical school
Facilities throughout the country,
the Johns Hopkins Medical
School is unable to expand its
incoming freshman class. Dr.
David Price, Director of Planning
for the Johns Hopkins Medical
Institutions, stated that
considering" our present
curriculum, most of the faculty
believe that 95 students a year is
the maximum figure for the
school now."
Basic Difficulty

basic dilliculty facing the school
is in the very limited space
allotted to laboratories. Price said
that there is no extra room in the
preset] t laboratory courses to
allow for an increase in
enrollment. "It's our major
bottleneck," he admitted.

News Briefs
New Turmoil...
To start off the new year, San Francisco State College is
gripped in a strike by one third of its faculty members, a supportive
strike by the unionized campus employees and. sporadic student
Picketing demonstrating and jeers.
The members of the American Federation of Teachers at the
college have supported student strikers who have boycotted classes
since November 6. There are 1,100 teachers and 18,000 students.
and minorities in both are striking for more say in the college's
policy decisions. This week classes were full, but professors sparce.
Until this development, Acting President S.I. Hayakawa was quite
Optimistic in keeping the school open. But now he says, "I don't
know how I am going to stop them from closing the school. But am
going to try." The College of San Mateo in California has been
rampaged in recent weeks by students in support of San Francisco
collegues.

While Gov. Talks Tough
Meanwhile, Governor Reagan has called for a get tough policy
in regard to campus turmoil. The new policy was stated in the
governor's "State of the State" message before a joint session of the
California legislature. This is the first year that the Republicans have
held a majority in both houses.
Reagan hopes to curb student and faculty disturbances by
increasing the pennies for disruptive action. He told the legislature,
"I will seek an omnibus program on the safety and security of our
educational institutions— to protect the teacher, the student and the
public."

Space Program Aided
Hopkins scientists observed last week a monitoring device
orbiting the earth to check solar radiation and cosmic rays. Dr. Carl
0. Bostrom headed the team at the Hopkins' Applied Physics
Laboratory in Silver Spring, which developed particle detectors for
an Interplanetary Monitoring Platform.
The platform called Explorer 34 is a 138 pound,
octagon-shaped satellite. It was launched in May 1967. Four tracking
stations were monitoring Explorer 38, and they sent their
information to Goddard Space Flight Center in Greenbelt, Maryland.
From there, it is forwarded to Houston for use of the astronauts or
their program planners.
Although the astronauts are shielded against radiation that
approaches being hazardous, bombardment of particles from an
unusual solar eruption is always a potential danger according to the
scientists. If such an eruption develops, the tracking stations will
step up their monitoring of the space platform. Solar proton
velocities can reach near the speed of light.

At its quarterly National
Council meeting in Ann Arbor,
Michigan in late December, SDS
took initial steps to change itself
from solely a college student
movement to a multi-class youth
movement. The National Council
also dealt with •the issues of
Women's Liberation, Inauguration
Day demonstrations and the
Tenth Anniversary of the Cuban
Revolution.
For the last year, SDS has
been discussing and debating the
traditional blue-collar working
class: its importance in modern
capitalism, its role in a movement
for revolutionary change, and
how best to link up with and
organize the "working class" for
such change. SDS has slowly
come to the belief that the
working class is a critical force in
this society, that it should play a
leading role in the movement for
revolutionary change, and that it
is of crucial importance at this
time that the Movement makes,
serious alliances with the working
class, especially its progressive
elements. Radicals emphasize this
by pointing to the important
effects of the worker-student
alliance during the French May
Rebellion.

organize in the Army,in the High
Schools, Working Class Colleges,
trade and technical schools, in the
streets, around these group
similarities and common forms of
oppression which give the lie to
the myth of the American Dream
and the American Consensus. The
formulators do not see youth as a
formal class, and while
maintaining that young and old
workers have more in common
than the young of different
classes, they see this proposal for
a "Revolutionary Youth
Movement" as a means of making
connections with the working
class. It is seen as a temporary
strategy for broadening the base
of the Movement to include the
working class on a significant
scale which will lead to a
movement for revolutionary
change dominated by the working
class.
The National Council also
passed a resolution aimed at
promoting the struggle for
Women's Liberation. SDS sees
that women, like black people
and young people, experience
certain forms of oppression
common to the group. The
primary forms of oppression are
economic: women are
discriminated against in job hiring
and promotion, women are paid
lower wages than men, women
serve as a reserve labor force to
replace men during wartime and
during strikes. Secondarily,
women take a back-seat role to
men socially and politically. The
ideas of the prim and proper
woman who "knows her place",
which is inculcated starting at the
youngest age possible, is still the
ideal in this society despite
certain progressive or "hip"
examples to the contrary. Women
are exploited sexually, both
commercially and by men
individually, i.e., not only the
"double standard" but also the
notion of the girl-friend or wife as
a possession. Women,
furthermore, internalize out of
necessity this value system and
these relationships. The
oppression of women as an
economic "class", by men in
social relationships and by
themselves through the process of
internalization occurs even within
the "Movement.' The women's

Labor Committees which lend
support (often critical) to labor
strikes and in turn try to gain
labor support for student
demands and actions. This
approach has met with varied
degrees of success, especially
during the massive strike now
going on at San Francisco State
College.
Many in SDS feel, however,
that this approach is too
mechanistic, either too
unsuccessful or too politically
compromising, and too unnatural.
What they do see is young people
of all classes faced with certain
common forms of oppression and
alienation. Youth face the draft,
youth are forced through an
authoritarian and alienating
educational system, youth are the
objects of the most massive sales
campaign ever mounted in the
history of American
capitalism...most of which is junk,
youth are denied due process and
equal protection in the courts,
youth are continually messed over
by the cops, youth are required to
do meaningless work, be it in the
schools or the work place. It is
also significant that young people
have the greatest rate of

in the forefront of the black

class people in the forefront of
the "white" movement, and
young workers in the forefront of
the labor insurgencies. Young
people as a group are turned off
by Mainstream America, and
turned on to other things.

NEW YORK, December 24
- Three militant high school
student organizations have
formed an alliance for future
actions and coordination. This is
an outgrowth of the massive
strike by high school students in
late November and early
December in protest against the
extended \ hours and days of
school which was part of the
settlement of the Teacher's Strike
this fall. The High School Student
Union, the High School Coalition
and the Afro-American Student
Association have formed the High
School Student Council. The
Council will consist of
representatives from the three
organizations and five members at
large. Its purpose will be to help
bridge communications and to
work Logether on a city-wide
basis.

The Draft - Part 103
Though there are ostensibly peace talks going on in Paris and
we are led to believe that this time the South Vietnamese will really
be taking more of a part in the fighting there, the draft still hangs
over the heads of college students facing graduation.
Therefore, as a public service, we offer the following
suggestions for those students who wish to vent their bitterness on
their local Selective Service Boards.
1 - Write a letter to your local board referring to your previous
letter of two weeks ago. (Naturally, there was no previous letter of
two weeks ago). Tell your board that you are awaiting their answer
and are surprised that they have not yet replied. The board's staff is
then obligated to search through their files for your letter, causing
universal grief.
2 - Write a letter to your board, using a fictitious name,
wondering why you have not received your first classification card.
Given a false return address. (If you have time write a dozen or so
letters to this effect). According to our information, when the board
fails to find records of the non-person, and fails to contact him
about the non-existence of his records, they will have to send
someone to investigate. The best method to use here, is to take a few
names from your local phone book who have addresses withint the
jurisdiction of your board.
3 - As a public-spirited citizen, alert your draft board to the
fact that you have heard of plans to raid their office and pour blood
in the 1-A files. This method is best used if you know of someone
(preferably someone you don't like) who plans to visit his draft
board on a specific day on some business. Give a good description of
him. A splendid time is guaranteed for all.
4 - Keep a diary of all the minute things that happen to you in
day-to-day life. Make a carbon for your own personal use, and send
the original closely-hand written 3 pages each day to your board,
preferably addressed to a specific ranking board member. At some
point in one of your daily missives, insert a question pertinent to
your draft status. If the question goes unanswered, write to your
board a few weeks later asking what their reply was to the question
posed in "my letter of the fifteenty... or sixteenth.., or
seventeenth."
5 - Send them a copy of this editorial,(we don't want to go
either).

By ED MENDELSOHN
The Presidential inaugural
ceremonies, soon to be renewed,
have had an interesting evolution.
Inaugurals have been held
indoors, have been held in three
different cities and have had
varying historical significance.
The Constitution provides
only that the President must take
an oath, which is all that is done
in cases of non-quadrennial
succession. However, George ,
Washington was understandably
honored in several communities
when he went north to New York
for the first inaugural in 1789.
This first ceremony was held
outdoors, and Mr. Washington
delivered a long inaugural address.
However, he had neglected to
bring his Bible with him and had
to acquire one in New York. That
the President will hold a Bible in
taking the required oath is as
certain as that he will attend the
ceremonies.
For Mr. Washington's
second inaugural, there seemed no
reason to have more than the
oath taking. Thomas Jefferson was
an especially earnest advocate of
simplicity, and there was a very
brief ceremony within the .Senate
chamber in Philadelphia. Mr.
Washington delivered a statement
of thanks, which may be
considered the shortest inaugural
address, but which was so brief as
to make it a tenable proposition
that there was no inaugural
address in 1793.
Outdoors
John Adams was
inaugurated March 4, 1797 in the
House chamber in Philadelphia,
and since then all inaugurals have
been in Washington, D.C. Mr.
Jefferson's own inaugurals were
not as simple as that which he had
prescribed for Mr. Washington.
Inaugurals alternated between the

chambers of the Senate and the
House until 1817, when there
wasa dispute between the two
Houses over the allocation of
tickets. James Monroe therefore
participated in the second
outdoor inauguration.
The ceremonies reverted to
the indoors until Andrew
Jackson, who desired a
government close to the people,
was inaugurated outdoors in
18_29. Afterwards his supporters
entered the White House, and
committed some property
damage, so that in the famous
words of Supreme Court Justice
Joseph Story of Massachusetts,
"the reign of King Mob seemed
triumphant."
Few inaugurations have
been equally open to
participation. Even then, and
again in the inauguration of
Zachary Taylor in 1849, there
were complaints of insufficient
refreshments. But no President
since has been inaugurated
indoors, despite such incidents as
the rain at James K. Polk's
inauguration in 1845.
No Notes
Only one president,
Franklin Pierce in 1853, delivered
his inaugural address without
reading from notes. Mr. Pierce
had been among the leading trial
lawyers of New Hampshire, and
his oratorical powers were quite
equal to this occasion.
There is 'no lack of
commentary on one of the
milestones of our history, the
inauguration of Abraham Lincoln
on March 4, 1861. To me it is
most arresting that, besides Mr.
Lincoln, so many of those who
played an important role in the
ceremony would not live to see
another President. Mr. Lincoln
was introduced by a former
colleague in the Winois State
Legislature, Senator Edward D.
Baker of Oregon, who died that

autumn at the Battle of Ball's
Bluff. During the inaugural
address Mr. Lincoln's hat was held
by his former adversary, Senator
Stephen A. Douglas, who also had
only months to live. Then the
oath was administered to Mr.
Lincoln by Chief Justice Roger B.
Taney, who had been criticized
by the former for his decision in
the Dred Scott case, and who was
to die on Columbus Day of 1864.
Big-Mouth Coolidge
The twentieth century has
seen two important changes, the
introduction of broadcasting and
the changing of the date from
March 4 to January 20. Radio
first covered the ceremonies on
March 4, 1925, at the
inauguration of Calvin Coolidge.
The oath of office was
administered by Chief Justice
William Howard Taft, himself
inaugurated on the same day
sixteen years before, who noted
that his voice was heard and
recognized in all parts of the
country. The first televised
coverage of the inauguration of
Harry S. Truman on January 20,
1949.
The first President
inaugurated on January 20,
following the enactment of
George Norris' Twentieth
Amendment, was Franklin D.
Roosevelt for his second term in
1937. Had this been the operative
date earlier, John Adams would
have been inhibited from
appointing John Marshall as Chief
Justice.
The inaugural ceremony is
significant as a symbol of unity.
The administering of the oath of
office by the head of the judicial
branch to the head of the
executive branch in front of the
legislative chamber illustrates the
fundamental cohesiveness of the
Federal government.

By ART LEVINE
Before attempting to review
the Beatles' album, I have a
confession to make: I'm a Beatle
teenybopper. When it comes to
Beatlerablia, I'm an insatiable
hog. I scour all the magazines,
newspapers, and rock journals,
my heart throbbing with a 13
year old's excitement, searching
for the merest mention of my
heroes' names. My,tolerance for
even the most inane trivia on the
Beatles is disgustingly enormous.
Is John Lennon's ex-wife writing
a children's book? Is Paul
McCartney's uncle's middle name
Rufus? If so, I'll know about it.
Furthermore, I spend endless
hours of discussion on the most
inconsequential nuances of every
Beatle album. There seems to be
no end to my absorption and
fascination with the Beatles.
Frankly, I'm hooked.
End of Narcissism
The new album is a step
down for the Beatles. Although it
is less intellectually satisfying
than Sgt. Pepper's, it is more fun.
Now for hip young intellectuals
bent on finding great meaning in
the Beatles, this new album is a
disappointment. Part of the
reason for this disappointment are
. the disclaimers of the Beatles
themselves, who say that a lot of
their songs are put-ons, rubbish,
nonsensical,. and meaningless. In
the good old days, one could
spend many fruitful hours poring
over the songs of the Beatles,
finding literary allusions and
hidden meanings to satisfy the
heart of any literary scholar.
Now, of course, we find we can't
find great meaning in obscure
songs like "I Am the Walrus"
because John Lennon won't let
us.
What the Beatles are doing,
and everybody else it seems, is
returning to their roots, their
past. This past was a simpler one,
with easy lyrics and a simple turn.
Songs like "Dizzy Miss Lizzie,"
"Love Me Do," and "P.S. I Love
You," and so on exemplify this
simplicity. The new Stones album
is a similar return to their roots,
which are rhythm and bluesy.

Bethlehem Steel
Loop Course Interviews:

FEBRUARY
10, 11, 1969

.
4

What is the Bethlehem Loop Course? It is our management development program for graduat?s
with bachelors' or advanced degrees.
The course starts early in July with four weeks of orientation at our home offices in Bethlehem,
Pa. Loopers attend lectures on every phase of the corporation's activities, and make almost daily
visits to a steel plant.
Steel Plant Loopers, who comprise a majority of the average loop class of 150 to 200 graduates,
proceed to various plants where they go through a brief orientation program before beginning
their on-the-job training assignments. Within a short time after joining the course, most loopers
are ready for assignments aimed toward higher levels of management.
How about other loopers? Our Sales Department loopers (30 or so) remain at the home office for
about a year of training. Most are then assigned to district offices where they take over established
accounts.
Fabricated Steel Construction loopers are trained in a drafting room, on a field erection project,
in a fabricating shop, and in an engineering office. A looper's first work assignment is based on
interests and aptitudes disclosed during this program.
Loopers in Accounting, Shipbuilding, Mining, Research, Traffic, Purchasing, Finance and Law,
General Services, and Industrial and Public Relations go through training programs tailored to
their types of work.
Where would YOU fit in? Check your degree or the one most similar to it.
MECHANICAL ENGINEERING—Engineering or mechanical maintenance departments of steel plants, fabricating works, mining operations, and shipyards. Fuel and
combustion departments. Supervision of production operations. Marine engineering assignments in Shipbuilding
Department. Also: Sales or Research.
METALLURGICAL ENGINEERING — Metallurgical
departments of Steel plants and manufacturing operations.
Engineering and service divisions. Technical and supervisory positions in steelmaking departments and rolling.
mills. Also: Research or Sales.
,CHEMICAL ENGINEERS—Technical and supervisory
positions in coke works, including production of byproduct chemicals. Fuel and combustion departments, including responsibility for operation and maintenance of air
and water 'pollution control equipment. Engineering and
Metallurgical departments. Steelmaking operations. Also:
Research or Sales.
INDUSTRIAL ENGINEERING —Positions in steel
plants, fabricating works, shipyards, and mines. Engineering and maintenance departments. Supervision of
steelmaking, rolling, manufacturing, and fabricating
operations. Also: Sales.
CIVIL ENGINEERING: Fabricated Steel Construction
assignments in engineering, field erection, or works management. Steel plant, mine, or shipyard assignments in
engineering, construction, and maintenance. Supervision
of production operations. Sales Department assignments
as line salesman or sales engineer (technical service to
architects and engineers).

ELECTRICAL ENGINEERING—Steel plant, fabricating works, mining operations, and shipyard electrical
engineering, construction, and maintenance departments.
Technical and supervisory positions in large production
operations involving sophisticated electrical and electronic equipment. Also: Research or Sales.
MINING ENGINEERING — Our Mining Department
operates coal and iron ore mining operations and limestone quarries, many of which are among the most modern and efficient in the industry. This 10,000-man activity
offers unlimited opportunities to mining engineers. Also:
Research.
NAVAL ARCHITECTS AND MARINE ENGINEERS:
Graduates are urged to inquire about opportunities in our
Shipbuilding Department, including the Central Technical Division, our design and engineering organization.
Also: Traffic.
OTHER TECHNICAL DEGREES—Every year we recruit loopers with technical degrees other than those listed
above. Seniors enrolled in such curricula are encouraged
to sign up for an interview.
ACCOUNTANTS—Graduates in accounting or business
administration (24 hours of accounting are preferred) are
recruited for training for supervisory assignments in our
3,000-man Accounting Department.
OTHER NON-TECHNICAL DEGREES — Graduates
with degrees in liberal arts, business, and the humanities
are invited to discuss opportunities in the Sales Department. Some non-technical graduates may be chosen to fill
openings in steel plant operations and other departments.

NOW'S THE TIME TO SIGN UP FOR AN INTERVIEW. And when you register at the placement office, be sure to pick up a copy of our booklet. "Careers with Bethlehem Steel and the
Loop Course.- It contains important information about the corporation and your opportunities
through the Loop Course.

BETHLEHEM STEEL

in the Plans for Progress Program

By RICH HOLLANDER
Sports Editor

The original Levering bacchanalia, otherwise known as the Fall
Sports Banquet, was held on December 16. Staged .and
choreographed by master of ceremonies, Henry Ciccarone, the three
119ur extravaganza clearly rivaled the Academy Awards in trophies if
not in comic talent. Ciccarone filtered out all the funny lines and
concentrated on the business of the evening. "...going to scout
Carnegie Mellon, Mr. Smith got me tickets on a small Italian airline."
The first order of business was digestion. An almost gruesome
task,- pertaining to some mysterious meat, wrapped in an oblong
shade around Thanksgiving' Day's stuffing, covered with brown
all-purpose gravy. There was a lemon surprise for dessert...that my
dentist would have loved. Our president, Dr. Gordon, rendered a few nonchalant
comments on the games he attended. He looked as in -place at a
sports banquet as General Eckert.
BARRETTE'S BOYS
Prefacing the soccer awards, Coach Gary Barrette gave the
classic line of the affair. "I thought this was going to be a joint
banquet and so far I've ended up eating a football." After that
unpalatable allusion, Barrette praised his soccermen who finished
third out of 17 teams in the Middle Atlantic Conference.
Recognition was givento Jay AB-Stars Rick Tobey, Art Guerin and
Mike Avery in the MAC; and to Tobey, Guerin, and Randy Miller in
the Mason-Dixon Conference. Hardly getting a change to enjoy a
Barrette monologue, Miller and Tobey, were up again capturing
places on the MI-South team. In the trophy department, Dave
Roberts, leading scorer, and Randy Miller, outstanding player, took
the honors. An engraved soccer ball was given by Mr. Barrette to
captain Mike Avery for outstanding sportsmanship: The Booster
Club awarded a mini-trophy to "unsung hero" Greg Sarau. Avery, on
behalf of the team, thanked trainers Leroy Brandimore and Steve
Bartlett and trundled over to Coach Barrette with a varsity "H Club"
jacket. In the '68 soccer swansong Avery announced that Randy
Miller and Dave Roberts were elected co-captains for '69.
SOTIR'S SORTIE
Once upon a while the Jay gridmen were 0-6-2. Two years
have gone by and in that period the varisty eleven have taken two
consectuvie MAC championships. The man to blame for this
achievement, head coach Alex Sotir, spelled out the ingredients in
his championship brew. Take a dash of administrative empathy, a
touch of studen enthusiasm and dump in lots of team pride and
bingo - a championship.
Nevertheless, the trophies went to the bodies who blocked,
'bruised and busted themselves to the championship. Co-captains
Don Yablonowitz and Willie Scroggs received game balls from
Carnegie-Mellon and Western Maryland respectively. The unsung
Boosters picked unsung heroes John Peck and Willie Scroggs for
awards. Don took home a silver cup in memory of Hopkins'
tOotballer Charles E. Aronhalt, who was killed in Vietnam in 1966:
For variety a plaque was given to Joe Cowen for team spirit. The
newly founded Huddle Club gave its second annual contribution
trophy to Phil Schrodel. This trophy was a high rise jqb and was the
gaudiest of the festivities. Representing the MAC, Marshall Turner
made the championship official. Mr. Bilgrave proved to be as
efficient a tie clip distributor as he is an administrator, calling off the
roster in 3 minutes and 6 seconds. Don, like his soccer counterpart,
gave the coaches jackets. Due to close balloting, the '69 team will
have tri-captains. They are Jim Lotto, Charlie Coker and Dan
Rosenfeld. Imagine if they did that in national elections.
IN THE BLUE JERSEY NUMBER 70
Ex-Colt Art D'onovan, a mastodon of a man, was the,guest
speaker. The football Hall of Famer strung together half humorous,
half pathetic anecdotes of football nostalgia. He peppered Dr.
Gordon with, "Well, you see Doctor. I went to college to play
football." Donovan didn't have to tell us that or the fact he came
from the Bronx. Both were quite apparent. After a detailed
description of a gridiron mauling, Donovan asserted,"We had alot of
fun."
We all did.

MARSHALL KAPP, varsity heavyweight grappler battles against foe from Lebanon Valley College. Jays won
match by score of 24-13 but Kapp lost his bout.

After enduring several years
of frustration because of a lack of
overall power, the varsity gapplers
have finally come into their own.
Beating two relatively
strong teams before Christmas,
the matmen take on the powerful
Indians of Delaware University at
home next Wednesday at 8:00
p.m. with the Baby Jays facing
the Delaware frosh at 6:45 p.m.
In their first match of the
season on December 14th, the
varsity wrestlers completely tore
apart the Shoremen of
Washington College, winning the
contest with a score of 35 to 5.
Rich Dryden, captain of the
team, won the 123 lb. class by
forfeit. Stan Konefal, wrestling in
his first varsity match, decisioned
Kiler by a score of 9-5. The match
was tied 2-2 going into the third
period when the Hopkins
sophomore reversed his opponent
twice and almost had a pin as the
bout ended.

finally won the match on a final
takedown, 6-5 defeating the
captain of the Washington College
team.
Jeff Parker, another
sophomore, wrestling at 145 lb.,
showed why he was last year's
best frosh grappler by going right
for a pin and landing it at exactly
1:09 into the match. Monte
lkemire, the 152 lb. senior from
Oklahoma, followed Parker's act
by pinning his opponent in 7:29.
Jack Hannemann, one of
the few juniors on the team,
continued the pinning ways of the
Jays by defeating his man in 6:01.
Hannemann was leading at the
time by 6-1. John Peck, 177 lb.
senior, who was the unluckiest
wrestler on the team last year,
showed everyone that the jinx
had ended. Peck decisioned
Pramm of Washington College,
6-1, and accumulated over 6
minutes of riding time.

Betta Upends Captain
Carl Betta, also wrestling in
his first varsity contest, fell
behind 2-0 in the first period,
came back to lead the Shoreman
4-3 at the end of the second, and

First Period Decisive
Bob Hyams, the other
junior on the team, defeated his
177 lb. foe in a rough and tumble
match. Charles Conway, another
first year varsity matman,
decisioned Filippi at 191 lb. by
the score of 8-7. It wasn't until
late in the third period that
Conway assured himself of the
win. Filippi was fourth in the
Mason-Dixon tournament last
year.
Marshall Kapp, a very
determined wrestler battling in his
first varsity bout, nearly pinned
his heavyweight opponent during
the first minute of the match; but
Kapp made an unfortunate error
and was pinned at 1:51. Fred
Ryland, wrestling exhibition,
decisioned his foe, 12-4.

All those players who have

We're No Patsies
Opening the home season
against the Flying Dutchmen of
Lebanon Valley College on
December 18, the grapplers were
faced with an experienced and
talented opposition. In previous
years, the Flying Dutchmen
always considered our match as a
means of boosting their record;
but this year, as last year the Blue
Jays came away with the biggest
laugh, beating LVC, 24-13.
Rich Dryden started his
1968-69 tour where he left off
last February before his arm
injury. Dryden easily defeated
Layne of LVC, pinning the 123

lb. foe in 5:45. Dryden was
beating him, 8-0 at the time.
Carl Betta was then down
with a severe virus infection and
was unable to wrestle. Coach Kyle
Smith decided to forfeit the 130
lb. class and have Stan Konefal
move up to 137 lb. The strategy
worked out beautifully as Konefal
decisioned Etchberger, 5-2.
Jeff Parker, who hates to
stay on the mat too long,
recorded his second straight pin;
this one also came in the first
period at 1:56. Monte Ikemire
lost to the Dutchmen's powerful
152 pounder, Rich Althouse, 7-2.
Jack Hanemann decisioned Koons
by the score of 12-7. The score
was tied 7-7 with a minute to go.
John Peck continued his
winning ways, pinning LVC's Bob
Helt in 4:09. Charles Conway,
wrestling in the 177 lb. class for
Bob Hyams who had a bad arm,
battled a tough opponent. Going
into the last period the score was
all tied, but Conway recorded a
near fall and an escape to gain a
9-7 victory.
Marshall Kapp lost the
unlimited bout when Thomas of
LVC pinned him in 3:26. Fred
Ryland, again wrestling an
exhibition bout, pinned his foe in
4:23.
The team is well rested after
the Christmas holidays. Betta is
over the virus and Hyams is
completely healed. Bob Sanborn,
injured early in December, is
slowly coming back to his form.
Winners of the paper bag
award, given after each match to
the wrestler who has been ridden
the longest period of-time, have
been: Conway for the Washington
match and Hanemann for the
LVC victory'. The bag,which is
placed outside the locker of the
lucky individual until the next
match, reads: "You can't even
fight your way out of this paper
bag, never mind another
wrestler." The award, to be sure,
is not one of the more coveted
prizes of the powerful Hopkins
matmen.

NEWS-LETTER

Natators Girding Berke Paces Varsity B-Ballers
For Crucial Meet In Victory Over Swarthmore
By JOSH TREEM
Wednesday, January 15 will
mark the crucial date in J.H.U.'s
varsity swimming season. Fresh
from two pre-Christmas victories
over Swarthmore and Towson
State, and with another win
hopefully in the offing against
PMC tomorrow at Homewood,
the Jays will tackle the University
of Delaware again at home.
First year coach Frank
Comfort considers this meet the
most important in Hopkins
swimming history, and has tried
to convey this attitude to his
swimmers. "Delaware is the one
really outstanding team we swim
in dual meet competition," he
stated. "They're in a class by
themselves."(Delaware does in
fact compete in the MAC
University division while Hopkins
swims in the college division.)
"We could go 10-1, or 9-2 for the
season and everyone would say
'good job', but as far as I'm
concerned this is the big one."
Any thought of beating
Delaware was dismissed as
ludicrous last year. And it is a
tribute to both coach and
swimmers that Hopkins can even
think of challenging Delaware.
Scouting reports indicate that the
contest will be extremely tight.
The Jays hope to have the meet
won before the final event, the
freestyle, where Delaware now
has an edge, and while all races
are crucial, the 50 and 100 yd.
freestyle and the 200 yd.
individual medley loon as key
contests.
Drawing Comfort
In any case, as the Jan. 15
deadline draws closer, certain
elements may work in the Jays
favor and could spell the
difference between victory or
defeat. First is the home pool
advantage. While this is a minor,
consideration because of the
excellent facilities, a partisan
crowd can only help Hopkins. In
addition, the bus ride and a night

meet might find Delaware a bit
tired.
Second is Delaware's
rigorous dual meet schedule
which has them swimming five
meets before meeting Hopkins,
and possibly the swimmers could
be psychologically tired. Third is
the psyche factor. Coach Comfort
has injected a determination into
the Jays previously unknown. As
the Bullets' slogan goes: "We have
a few scores to settle."
Intangible Difference
Indeed, the squad is
pointing for this contest, and
although Delaware must be aware
of the Jays' improvement,
hopefully they will not be taking
the meet as seriously as Comfort's
charges. This intangible could
make all the difference. The meet
is scheduled for 8:30 p.m. on
Wed., Jan. 15, at Homewood
pool.
Tomorrow, the Jays tangle
with PMC at Homewood at 3:00
p.m. Last year Hopkins nipped
the Cadets 47-46. This year's
meet could be as close but it is
unlikely. Mr. Comfort is viewing
the meet as a final tune-up for
Delaware and is not cutting down
on practices. The attitude around
the locker room is one of
confidence. However, PMC has an
outstanding freestyle sprinter and
two fine backstrokers. Heavily
laden with sophomores the Cadets
are basically an unknown
quantity in MAC circles and could
spell trouble for a complacent
Hopkins crew.
In the two meets before
Christmas break, Hopkins easily
beat Swarthmore 53-40 and then
swamped Towson State 65-28.
Highlighting the Towson meet
were Marc Solomon who qualified
for the NCAA college nationals in
the 200 yd. butterfly, Mike
O'Donnell who set a varsity
record in the 200 yd.
breaststroke, and Brian Turner's
100 yd. freestyle record (52.5).

Freshmen Five Down
Gilman in Easy Victory
By MIKE SHORE
The frosh basketball team,
under the direction of Coach
Gary Barrette, had a busy week
before the holiday break, winning
2 games against 1 loss, and
showing off some high quality
To open their season, the
team met Gilman High School,
and coasted to an easy 65-53
victory. The game was never in
the slightest doubt, and all of our
men were given ample chance to
play and show off their talents in
a game situation.
The next game was the first
half of a Saturday evening
Swarthmore Frosh/Varsity
doubleheader. It too was an easy
victory, 84-66.
The high point of this one
was a tremendously spectacular
offensive show by Gary
Handleman. He broke the modern
Hopkins freshman scoring record
by racking up 40 points. He was
16 for 22 from the court for a
72% shooting average, and 8 for 9
from the foul line. Hal Grinberg
was also a big help to the effort
with 17 points.
Playing against a team from
Catholic University, made up
entirely of scholarship players,
our men put on a good
performance and came to within

one point of winning at the end.
The final score was 81-80.
Without a few misfortunes the
frosh could very well have beaten
a team which averaged several
inches taller, and supposedly was
a better class of basketball team

nasty cut on his ear and had to
come out. Then Mike Kohler tore
some ligaments in his ankle and
also left the game. Soon after
John Lilly was taken out by
Barrette because he was in foul
trouble.

It has become increasingly
evident in the past several years
that an acute shortage of trained
doctors may be soon facing the
country.
()pinion is near-unanimously pessimistic. The U.S.
General Surgeon, for example,
estimates that we will need
11,000 M.D.'s a year by 1975 yet
the Association of American
Medical Colleges (AAMC) reports
thii the chalices of producing
more than 9,450 per year by then
is very slim.
lin to
the
prospects of even approaching the
needed increase in graduating
M.D. s is very unlikely. This year
for example, there are
approximately 3.9 doctors per
100,000 while in 1955 the figure
rested at 4.2_ The figures appear
even worse when it is realized that
patients today see their doctor
twice as often as they did 30
years ago.
Overworked
in today's society,
therefore, are few and often
overworked.
In response to the growing
awareness of the great difficulties
towards which Hie country is
moving, there has developed in
recent years, a cry for medical
schools to increase the number of
graduates per year. One
outstanding critic of medical
policies today, Dr. John B.
deC.M. Saunders, former dean
Doctors

for example, is admitting this year
100 extra students to the third
year of the medical program.
These students come primarily
from the seven two-year medical
schools in the country. Because
the two-year schools do not offer
a medical degree, the admission of
the 100 students represents a
total increase in the number 'of
M.D. degrees given.
Dr. Yardley believes that
this admission of students into
the third year will allow for
maximum utilization of
institutional facilities.
Dr. Price also noted that the
Advisory Board is presently
preparing a feasibility study of
the requirements necessary for
increasing the present total
enrollment. After the report is
complete, Dr. Price indicated that
the Medical can then begin to
think in terms of long-range
expansion and eventual increases
in doctors produced by the
School.

and chancellor of the University
of California School of Medicine,
believes that schools across the
country should increase
enrollment by between 15 and 20
per cent. Such a move, he argues,
would produce as many new
doctors as 12 to 16 additional
medical schools.
Despite this need for
expansion of the medical school
Facilities throughout the country,
the Johns Hopkins Medical
School is unable to expand its
incoming freshman class. Dr.
David Price, Director of Planning
for the Johns Hopkins Medical
Institutions, stated that
considering" our present
curriculum, most of the faculty
believe that 95 students a year is
the maximum figure for the
school now."
Basic Difficulty

basic dilliculty facing the school
is in the very limited space
allotted to laboratories. Price said
that there is no extra room in the
preset] t laboratory courses to
allow for an increase in
enrollment. "It's our major
bottleneck," he admitted.

because of limitations of facilities,
